title: Peter Hurley's 3-Light Strobe Headshot Setup
summary: Photographer Peter Hurley demonstrates how to replicate his signature flat, window-light look using a three-light strobe setup. He details the specific arrangement of softboxes and strip lights to create a triangular aperture and explains critical positioning techniques to ensure even illumination without unwanted shadows.

steps.action: Arrange three strobe lights in a triangular formation to mimic a flat, window-light source.
Position the camera to shoot through the smallest possible opening in the center of the light setup.
Ensure all modifiers and flash heads are from the same manufacturer to maintain color consistency.
Use a standard rectangular softbox for the bottom light and strip boxes for the side lights to keep the triangle configuration tight.
Place the subject behind the point where the lights converge; placing them in front will cause shadowing.

key_takeaways: A triangular strobe setup can effectively mimic the look of continuous window light.
Using strip boxes on the sides allows the lighting setup to be more condensed than using three standard softboxes.
Mixing modifiers from different manufacturers can lead to color shifts on the subject.
The subject must be positioned behind the light convergence point to achieve a truly flat light without side shadows.
